Theory of emotions and economic analysis:
a review1
Emmanuel Petit*
Since Elster’s seminal review [1998], an abundant literature has revealed the growing interest of economists in the question of emotions. The introduction of emotion into economic analysis has been carried out essentially from a psychological and neurological conception of emotion. Developing a richer and more complete economy of emotions makes it necessary to also draw on other approaches to emotion, notably from sociology, anthropology, history and philosophy. The aim of this article is to contribute to enriching the work of economists in this field by proposing a multidisciplinary state of the art that synthesizes the knowledge derived from the theory of emotions. The first step is to identify the major stages in the construction of this theory and to extract the essential properties of emotions. The aim is then to illustrate how this knowledge has been mobilized in economic analysis, taking into account the diversity of approaches characteristic of the discipline.

Introduction
Since Elster's seminal review [1998], an abundant literature has
revealed the growing interest of economists in the question of emotions (Loewenstein [2000], Camerer et al.

[2005], Rick et Loewenstein [2008],
Lerner et al.
[2015], Petit [2009, 2015], Dunning et al.

[2017], Gomes [2017],
Winter [2017], Wälde et Moors [2017], Tkach [2019], Rolls [2019]).

As in many academic disciplines, economists have accompanied what historians have called "the emotional turn" (Plamper [2010]), an extraordinary craze born in the mid-1990s for the study of emotions. In economics, emotions are today mainly mobilized and studied in an experimental framework and then introduced into behavioral models in order to improve existing models of human behavior. The "economics of emotions" (Petit [2015]) has made it possible to "revisit" the model of perfect rationality (Elster [1996], Kahneman [2012], Rolls [2019]), has introduced a plurality of social and/or moral motivations (Jourdheuil and Petit [2015]) and has led to new modalities of intervention by public authorities such as emotional paternalism (Schultz et al. [2007]). The introduction of emotion into economic analysis was carried out
essentially from a psychological and neurological conception of emotion. As suggested by Elster [1998], this conception made it possible (i) to disturb emotion in categories that could be easily mobilized by economists, (ii) to give it a functional (multi-component) definition particularly adapted to the methodological individualism practiced in experimental and behavioral economics and above all (iii) to provide precise and effective instruments for measuring and inducing emotions. The theory of emotions that was gradually established during the 20th century, however, covers a much broader field of analysis than that taken into account by psychology and neuroscience. Other disciplines – such as sociology, philosophy, anthropology, history or literature – have also constructed an elaborate and fruitful theory of emotions. Recent work on the theory of emotions also shows that there is now a convergence between approaches that were once opposed and considered incompatible (biology vs. anthropology, psychology vs. sociology). Developing a richer and more complete “economy of emotions” makes it necessary to know and draw on the different approaches to emotion, without limiting ourselves to the sole conception of psychology and/or neurology. The aim of this review is therefore to contribute to enriching the work of economists in this field by proposing a multidisciplinary state of the art that synthesizes the knowledge derived from the theory of emotions. First, it is a question of identifying the main stages in the construction of this theory and extracting the essential properties of emotions (2). The aim then is to illustrate – as extensively as possible but without claiming to be exhaustive – how this knowledge has been used in economic analysis, taking into account the diversity of approaches characteristic of the discipline (3). We will conclude this review of the literature on the theory and economics of emotions by discussing and identifying the most fruitful and promising areas of research for economists (4).

2.

The science of emotions:
expression, behavior, and social construction
It is possible to juxtapose two major conceptions in contemporary scientific approaches to emotion23. First, there are the authors who consider that emotions correspond to an objective empirical reality that can be defined, analyzed, evaluated, and broken down. Schematically, the proponents of this first trend are more located in the life sciences, in the medical sciences, or in experimental sciences such as psychology or neuroscience. Within this first trend, there are, on the one hand, those who give primacy to the bodily, physiological, biological dimension of emotion (2.1) and, on the other hand, those who, by relativizing the scope of the body, reveal the importance of cognition and psychological processes (2.2). Other authors, on the contrary, argue that emotions should be considered rather as objects on which we can formulate a discourse without claiming an operational measurement.

These authors share the idea that the human mind bases its capacity for knowledge on relationships
2.

This is naturally a schematic juxtaposition that allows the question of emotion to be approached with clarity and relative simplicity, especially for the uninitiated. However, the reader must keep in mind that the porosity, contiguity and overlap between the work of researchers belonging to different disciplines (neurology, sociology, social psychology, anthropology, philosophy, etc.) is much greater than what the following presentation of the theory of emotions suggests. Some works in particular are explicitly on the border between these disciplines (for example, overlapping neuroscience and history as an illustration (see in this regard the evocatively titled work by Smail [2007]).

In the following, we refer to the references and original editions of the texts or works of the authors cited.

For extensive and recent disciplinary academic reviews on the theory of emotions, the reader may consult in particular Lewis et al. [2010] and Tcherkassof [2008] in psychology, Panksepp [2004] in neuroscience, Stets and Turner [2014] in sociology, Goldie [2009] in philosophy, Beatty [2019] in anthropology, Biess and Gross [2014] in philosophy of science, Hoggett and Thompson [2012] and Nussbaum [2013] in political science, Plantin [2011] in communication sciences.
The history of emotions has been remarkably documented by Corbin et al.
For a historical introduction, see also Plamper [2015] as well as the articles by Boquet and Nagy [2011, 2016].
For a historical reading of the word “emotion”, refer to Dixon [2012]. The reader will also find a summary of the place of emotion in art in Bernardet al.
